info:
"verbs with prepositions" (verbos con preposiciones) in Spanish. In these cases, certain verbs require a specific preposition (such as "para" or "a") before an infinitive verb (like "ganar" or "nadar") to complete their meaning.

Understanding Verbs with Prepositions:
"Para" + Infinitive: Indicates purpose or goal.

Example: Se esforzó mucho para ganar la competencia.
(She tried hard to win the competition.)

"A" + Infinitive: Indicates direction, movement, or the beginning of an action.

Example: Aprendieron a nadar en el verano.
(They learned to swim in the summer.)

Why These Prepositions Matter:
In Spanish, many verbs naturally connect with a specific preposition.

Some verbs use "a," "de," "en," "por," or "para" to link to an infinitive or another phrase.

Changing the preposition can change the meaning of the sentence.
native_answer: He/She quit smoking years ago.
answer: Dejó de fumar hace años.
audio_dir: Dejó de fumar hace años.

(They learned to swim in the summer.)

Why These Prepositions Matter:
In Spanish, many verbs naturally connect with a specific preposition.

Some verbs use "a," "de," "en," "por," or "para" to link to an infinitive or another phrase.

Changing the preposition can change the meaning of the sentence.
native_answer: He/She fought to get the promotion.
answer: Luchó por conseguir el ascenso.
audio_dir: Luchó por conseguir el ascenso.

"A" + Infinitive: Indicates direction, movement, or the beginning of an action.

(They learned to swim in the summer.)

Why These Prepositions Matter:
In Spanish, many verbs naturally connect with a specific preposition.

Some verbs use "a," "de," "en," "por," or "para" to link to an infinitive or another phrase.

Changing the preposition can change the meaning of the sentence.
native_answer: He/She asked about enrolling in the course.
answer: Preguntó sobre inscribirse en el curso.
audio_dir: Preguntó sobre inscribirse en el curso.

info:
"verbs with prepositions" (verbos con preposiciones) in Spanish. In these cases, certain verbs require a specific preposition (such as "para" or "a") before an infinitive verb (like "ganar" or "nadar") to complete their meaning.

Understanding Verbs with Prepositions:
"Para" + Infinitive: Indicates purpose or goal.

Example: Se esforzó mucho para ganar la competencia.
(She tried hard to win the competition.)

"A" + Infinitive: Indicates direction, movement, or the beginning of an action.

Example: Aprendieron a nadar en el verano.
(They learned to swim in the summer.)

Why These Prepositions Matter:
In Spanish, many verbs naturally connect with a specific preposition.

Some verbs use "a," "de," "en," "por," or "para" to link to an infinitive or another phrase.

Changing the preposition can change the meaning of the sentence.
native_answer: He/She threatened to resign.
answer: Amenazó con renunciar.
audio_dir: Amenazó con renunciar.

Why These Prepositions Matter:
In Spanish, many verbs naturally connect with a specific preposition.

Changing the preposition can change the meaning of the sentence.
native_answer: He/She counted on receiving support from his/her team.
prompt: Contó ______ recibir apoyo de su equipo.
answer: Contó con recibir apoyo de su equipo.
audio_dir: Contó con recibir apoyo de su equipo.

native_answer: They gave advice on managing time.
answer: Dieron consejos sobre manejar el tiempo.
audio_dir: Dieron consejos sobre manejar el tiempo.
